Hearing.Directory: <table-of-content>C O N T E N T S</table-of-content> <peopleSpeaker> HR </peopleSpeaker> <peopleinfo>To expand sanctions against Iran with respect to the ballistic missile program of Iran and for other purposes Amendment in the nature of a substitute to HR offered by</peopleinfo> <peopleSpeaker> the Honorable Edward R Royce</peopleSpeaker> <peopleinfo>a Representative in Congress</peopleinfo> <peopleSpeaker> from the State of California</peopleSpeaker> <peopleinfo>and chairman Committee on Foreign Affairs Amendment to the amendment in the nature of a substitute to HR offered by: The Honorable Steve Chabot a Representative in Congress from the State of Ohio The Honorable Ron DeSantis</peopleinfo> <peopleSpeaker> HR </peopleSpeaker> <peopleinfo>To encourage visits between the United States and Taiwan at all levels and for other purpose</peopleinfo> <option>APPENDIX</option> <option>Markup notice.................................................... 76 Markup minutes................................................... 77 Markup summary................................................... 79 </option> <Doc-title>IRAN BALLISTIC MISSILES AND INTERNATIONAL SANCTIONS ENFORCEMENT ACT; AND TAIWAN TRAVEL ACT</Doc-title> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="">Committee on Foreign Affairs,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="">Washington, DC.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker=""> The committee met, pursuant to notice, at 9:30 a.m., in room 2172 Rayburn House Office Building, Hon. Edward Royce (chairman of the committee) presiding. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Royce">The committee will come to order.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Royce">Pursuant to notice, we meet today to mark up two bipartisan measures. Without objection, all members may have 5 days to submit statements or extraneous materials on today's business.</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>[The information referred to follows:]H.R.</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker=""> As members were notified yesterday, we intend to consider today's measures en bloc and so without objection the following items previously provided to members and also in your packets will be considered en bloc and are considered as read: H.R. 1698, the Iran Ballistic Missiles and Sanctions Enforcement Act, including the Royce Amendment 36 in the nature of a substitute to H.R. 1698, Chabot Amendment Number 3, <greek-l>the Santos deg.DeSantis Amendment Number 57, Schneider Amendment Number 2, Sherman Amendment Number 30, Sherman Amendment Number 31, Zeldin Amendment Number 32; and H.R. 535, the Taiwan Travel Act as introduced. 1698 H.R. 1698 Chabot amendment DeSantis amendment deg. Schneider amendment deg. Sherman #30 Sherman #31 Zeldin amendment <H.R. 535 </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Chairman Royce">I now recognize myself to speak on today's business. So today we consider H.R. 1698. This is the Iran Ballistic Missiles and International Sanctions Enforcement Act. It responds to the regime's continued pursuit of intercontinental ballistic missiles and dangerous conventional weapons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Royce">As we heard at our hearing yesterday, there is bipartisan agreement that we must continue to respond to the full range of threats that Iran poses to our national security and that of our allies and partners.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Royce">That means going after Iran's support for terrorism as we did last month by marking up two strong bills targeting Iran's leading terrorist proxy and that is Hezbollah.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Royce">It also means targeting Iran's development of intercontinental ballistic missiles and dangerous conventional weapons and that's what this bill does.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Royce">It requires a comprehensive investigation to identify and designate the companies and the banks and the individuals both inside and outside of Iran which supply the regime's missile and conventional weapons programs and it sanctions those entities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Royce">And I should note that we had an excellent hearing on Iran yesterday and our subcommittees have had excellent hearings for which I thank them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Royce">I appreciate members' concerns regarding the future of the Iran deal, on both sides. This isn't an easy issue. But this bipartisan bill, which we have before us today with over 300 co-sponsors, this bill is not and should not be a referendum on the nuclear deal.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Royce">I welcome the amendments considered in the en bloc that seek to strengthen this bill's impact on Iran's missile program.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Royce">I want to add a note of thanks to the members on both sides of the aisle who contributed to this bill with their thoughtful amendments--to Mr. Chabot, Mr. DeSantis, Mr. Schneider, Mr. Sherman, and Mr. Zeldin.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Royce">As former Secretary of Defense Ash Carter warned, the I in ICBM stands for intercontinental, ``which means having the capability from flying from Iran to the United States.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Royce">There is no question that the U.S. must take strong action now to curb Iran's dangerous pursuit of ballistic missiles.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Royce">So moving on to our other measure that we are taking up today, I want to thank Representative Steve Chabot for authoring H.R. 535. This is the Taiwan Travel Act.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Royce">Currently, the State Department enforces self-imposed restrictions on official travel between the United States and Taiwan. This bill denounces that practice by encouraging more frequent official visits including at the highest levels that will serve to further strengthen the critical U.S.-Taiwan partnership.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman Royce">This bill builds off legislation we passed out of the committee last month, which addressed Taiwan's exclusion from the World Health Assembly.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman Royce"> I now recognize the ranking member, Mr. Eliot Engel, for his remarks. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Engel</speaker> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Engel">Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Thank you for calling this markup.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Engel">This has been a busy week, Mr. Chairman, as we all wait to learn what the administration plans to do about the Iran deal.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Engel">This morning we have two bipartisan measures before us and that is no surprise because this committee is accustomed to working in a bipartisan way.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Engel">We think that foreign policy should be bipartisan and that partisanship should stop at the river's edge, and that is the way we have conducted ourselves during these past 5 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Engel">But, apparently, the administration doesn't agree. We learned through reporting that last evening the President's national security advisor, General McMaster, and Secretary of State Tillerson briefed Republican members on the administration's plans.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Engel">Policy toward Iran is of the highest national importance. We must stand together to confront these threats and, frankly, partisan briefings simply do not help. So let's get this right and stop the political games that the administration is playing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Engel">If reporting is accurate, the administration plans to decertify the deal and push for Congress to pass legislation to change parts of it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Engel">I am not quite sure how that would work. Congress has a role to play in foreign policy. But we cannot pass a law to unilaterally change an international agreement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Engel">If the administration wants to change the nuclear deal--and I would be the first to say there are areas which can be improved or strengthened--I want to remind everybody I voted against the deal 2 years ago--then the administration needs to work with our allies and negotiate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Engel">We can do this. There is time before areas of the agreement sunset. Let us put our heads together with our friends in London, Paris, Berlin, and the EU and see to it that all pathways to a bomb are cut off for Iran in perpetuity. But let us do it right. Don't blow up the agreement to save it. We will come out worse in the end.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Engel">If the administration needs certain authorities, that's where we have a job to do. But this talk of decertifying the agreement and kicking it to Congress for some sort of magical fix just doesn't make sense.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Engel">I wish I had more clarity on what the White House plans to do but the White House apparently feels the Democratic members don't need any kind of briefings.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Engel">I am, frankly, irked that many of us are being kept in the dark. That said, I am a co-sponsor of the ballistic missile legislation and I plan to support it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Engel">I am ready to work with Chairman Royce to pass more sanctions on Iran. But I am more curious why the tough sanctions law the President signed in August hasn't been put to use yet.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Engel">We hear a lot of talk from the White House, but so far the only action when it comes to Iran is this plan to decertify the deal.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Engel">I agree with my friend, the chairman. Let us enforce the hell out of the sanctions we have.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Engel">So I will support this bill but I have a lot of questions about what the administration plans to do in the hours and days ahead and, again, I am concerned about legislating on Iran when only a few members have the full picture of what's about to happen.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Engel">Next, I am grateful to Representatives Chabot and Sherman for their strong leadership on Taiwan and, in particular, for introducing the Taiwan Travel Act.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Engel">I am a strong supporter of Taiwan. I visited there many times including with the chairman, who has been a longstanding champion and highly regarded expert on Taiwan issues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Engel">Taiwan is a flourishing multi-party democracy of more than 20 million people with a vibrant free-market economy. It's a leading trade partner of the United States alongside much bigger countries like Brazil and India.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Engel">Over the past 60 years, the U.S.-Taiwan relationship has undergone dramatic changes and Taiwan's development into a robust and liberal democracy underscores the strong friendship our two countries share today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Engel">The cornerstone of our relationship is the Taiwan Relations Act passed by Congress in 1979. It has been instrumental in maintaining peace and security across the Taiwan Straits and in East Asia, and serves as the official basis for friendship and cooperation between the United States and Taiwan. Congress has played a major role in defining what our bilateral relationship looks like.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Engel">Given the possibility that the new administration may want to revisit regulations and guidance toward Taiwan, the Taiwan Travel Act is timely.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. Engel">This measure puts Congress on record saying the United States Government should encourage more regular, substantive, and senior level engagement between American and Taiwanese officials and reaffirms that our policy should be to allow such visits to occur at all levels of government.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. Engel">This is the sort of engagement and support we would like to see for our close friends and partners in Taipei. That is why I support this measure and encourage all members to do the same.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. Engel"> Again, Mr. Chairman, thank you for convening this markup and I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Chairman Royce">Thank you, Mr. Engel.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Do any other members seek recognition? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Smith</speaker> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. Smith"> </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Smith</speaker> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Mr. Smith">Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. Smith">As we heard yesterday in testimony from General Wald, the Iran deal ``places Iran on a trajectory to become as an intractable challenge as North Korea is today and, possibly, worse.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Mr. Smith">The general noted that while Pyongyang's relentless pursuit of nuclear weapons has only deepened its isolation and driven it toward bankruptcy, the JCPOA is doing the opposite for Iran.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Mr. Smith">It was clear, Mr. Chairman, from the beginning that this deal was deeply flawed. You said it. I said it. Many members of this committee on both sides of the aisle said it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Mr. Smith">It was clear as well that it was based on a fundamentally misguided premise that Iran's manifest desire for nuclear weapons could be considered separate from its development of a delivery capability for that weapon or from the rest of Iran's violent campaign for regional hegemony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. Smith">It should be self-evident that a nuclear warhead without a delivery vehicle is not going very far very fast. Iran's ballistic missile program is inseparable from its desire to impose nuclear blackmail on the United States, Israel, and other regional friends and allies.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Mr. Smith">Iran also exports its extremist revolution through the proliferation of conventional weapons to terrorist proxies. The Iranian nuclear deal, as we all know, gave Iran an infusion of an estimated $115 billion in unfrozen assets and, as John Kerry said in an interview that was carried by CNN, that we don't know where that money is going and it probably will end up in the terrorists' hands, not to mention other financial inducements like the $1.7 billion in small bills.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Mr. Smith">As we heard yesterday, this money has helped Iran to extend its malign influence to an unprecedented extent across the region in Syria, in Iraq, in Lebanon, and in Yemen.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Mr. Smith">H.R. 1698, the Iran Ballistic Missiles and International Sanctions Enforcement Act, enjoys broad bipartisan support and has a huge number of co-sponsors--some 320.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Mr. Smith">The bill expands sanctions against organizations and individuals that facilitate Iran's ballistic missile program as well as its trade in conventional weapons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="56" speaker="Mr. Smith">It is critical to our national security and that of our allies in the region, especially our good friend and ally, Israel.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="57" speaker="Mr. Smith"> I yield back and I ask unanimous consent that the full statement be made a part of the record. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="58" speaker="Chairman Royce">Without objection.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="59" speaker="Chairman Royce"> We now go to Mr. Sherman. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Sherman</speaker> <paragraph paraId="60" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Mr. Chairman, thank you for bringing these excellent bills up. For 20 years, I have had a commitment to the security of Taiwan and countering the threat of Iran.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="61" speaker="Mr. Sherman">H.R. 535 I think should enjoy the support of everyone here and I have studied it as ranking member of the Asia Subcommittee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="62" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Taiwan has 23 million people. We have $85 billion of two- way trade. Any country near that important to us we would have meetings at the highest levels of government.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="63" speaker="Mr. Sherman">This bill expresses a sense of Congress that it should be U.S. policy to encourage government visits at all levels between the United States and Taiwan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="64" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Now, it is true that officials have traveled from Taiwan to the United States at various conferences. They participate in the meetings in the United States regarding the environment and global anti-terror campaigns.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="65" speaker="Mr. Sherman">But when it comes to the senior most Taiwanese national officials, we don't allow them to come to Washington. Taiwan's defense Foreign Minister and President have come to the United States this year but not Washington, DC, and not to meet in formal meetings in U.S. Government buildings.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="66" speaker="Mr. Sherman">There is only one beneficiary of this program and that is myself and the 30th Congressional District since it is a matter--since the place most visited by senior Taiwanese officials is the Sheraton Universal Hotel in my district. As wonderful as those meetings are, it would be much better if the meetings were at the State Department and here in the United States Congress.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="67" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Encouraging greater level of high-level visits and dialogue as mentioned the bill would ease Taiwan's international isolation and reaffirm the U.S. political and security commitments to Taiwan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="68" speaker="Mr. Sherman">As to H.R. 1698, the Iran Ballistic Missiles Act, this is an important act to make it plain that Iran's violations of U.N. Security Council resolutions regarding not only ballistic missiles but also the transfer of weapons must be responded to, and that is why I am pleased to be one of the 320 co-sponsors of this important legislation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="69" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Thank you for including my two amendments, the first of which requires the President to submit periodic reports on the illicit activities of supposedly civilian aircraft controlled by Iran.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="70" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Are they using them to take materiel to Assad, to the Houthis, and others? Are they using them to move chemical or biological weapons? Are they using them for terrorist acts like they did in Bulgaria a decade or two ago?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="71" speaker="Mr. Sherman">This is important because we are called upon to allow the sale of U.S. planes--supposedly civilian planes--to Iran. We should know what their existing civilian planes are used for.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="72" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Second, it calls for the President to report after each missile test the technical details of the test--the trajectory, duration, range.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="73" speaker="Mr. Sherman">I want to point out that some or all of these reports can be classified and some portions, clearly, should be.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="74" speaker="Mr. Sherman">The United States, clearly, provides the same information about North Korean missile tests that this bill calls on them to provide with regard to Iranian nuclear tests.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="75" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Such information will provide better assessments for the capacity of these missiles and help Congress do its job.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="76" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Finally, when it comes to sanctions on Iran, we need the toughest sanctions with the best explanation--tough sanctions so that Iran gets the message--the good explanation so that Europe and Asia support what we are doing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="77" speaker="Mr. Sherman">That is why I am pleased that this bill focuses on Iran's violation of U.N. Security Council resolutions dealing with missiles and weapons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="78" speaker="Mr. Sherman">The worst reason we could give is to say we are imposing sanctions to deliberately shred the nuclear deal. If we do that, Europe won't enforce the new sanctions and will not join us in them, and Europe will think it's fine for Iran to stop even pretending to live under its commitments under the deal.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="79" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Equally tough sanctions imposed because of what Iran is doing in Syria, what they are doing in missiles, what they are doing to violate U.N. Security Council resolutions gives us a chance of international support and leaves in place the benefits that we do get, and we do get some benefits from the Iran nuclear deal.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="80" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Finally, I would point out that in this room several of us, including myself, asked Secretary Kerry in 2015 were we allowed under the JCPOA to adopt sanctions because of Iran's support for terrorism, holding our hostages, and supporting Assad.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="81" speaker="Mr. Sherman">And the answer from Secretary Kerry is we are free to adopt additional sanctions as long as they are not a phony excuse for just taking the whole pot of the past ones and putting them back.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="82" speaker="Mr. Sherman">So let us impose the sanctions that Iran has earned from its evil activities and let's just make sure they pass the test of not being phony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="83" speaker="Mr. Sherman"> And I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="84" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Mr. Rohrabacher. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rohrabacher</speaker> <paragraph paraId="85" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">Thank you very much, and again, I'd like to thank you and Congressman Eliot Engel for the leadership on this issue.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="86" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">We have seen this committee on numerous occasions focus on what could be one of the gravest threats to the wellbeing of the American people that we face today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="87" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">In fact, I would probably put it at the most important. We have an unstable regime. We have a group of religious fanatics controlling the Iranian Government and our efforts to prevent the lunacy that comes out of that regime from getting into possession of nuclear weapons is vital to the security and wellbeing of the people of the United States.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="88" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">So I thank both of you for keeping us focused on this issue. Let me note that 20 years ago when I was here I remember a similar situation when we were facing the possibility that a lunatic in North Korea would get their hands on nuclear weapons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="89" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">And we went out of our way. We were assured by the administration that sanctions and incentives like giving cash would do the trick, and it didn't.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="90" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">The fact is we have had sanctions on North Korea and they did not work. The fact is we gave North Korea $4 billion to $5 billion, and not only did it not work, it probably facilitated their nuclear weapons program by giving them some other money that was then fungible to channel into the development--long- term development of a nuclear weapon.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="91" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">We have unleashed $150 billion into the control of the mullah regime in Iran. These are people who believe that we represent Satan to them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="92" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">The United States represents a Satanic force in the world that needs to be wiped out. That is what they believe. We have to face that reality.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="93" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">If we don't face that reality, we are going to face the same situation that we face in North Korea today. Yeah, wishful thinking. That was 20 years ago, and we facilitated North Korea to getting into this position.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="94" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">Again, sanctions alone will not work. But we should make sure that we move forward with all the things that we can do short of a military confrontation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="95" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">Sanctions is certainly one of them, and the second part, however, I think we have to bite the bullet and realize that in a nuclear age, we sometimes will have to take actions against governments that we would not necessarily want to disturb. We let them sit there. We'd have to take actions, and it doesn't necessarily mean sending American troops into action and into military confrontation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="96" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">Instead, which, during the Reagan years--I am very proud to have played a role in developing what they called the Reagan Doctrine, which was go out and try to find out who the enemies of your enemy are and then help those people to do the fighting for you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="97" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">And in this case, Iran is filled with people who hate the mullah regime. They are oppressed by the mullah regime. Persians--young Persians marched, in fact, 8 years ago, seeking our help, and we rebuked them. And instead, we should be reaching out to these young Persians who hate the mullah regime and want to live at peace, want to build an economy and not nuclear weapons. Let us reach out them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="98" speaker="Mr. Rohrabacher">Let us reach out to the Baluch, a people who are oppressed in Iran. Let us reach out to the Kurds. There are more Kurds in Iran than there are in Iraq, for example. There are Azaris that feel they are oppressed.
